results.title: System 6: a fragile nest
results.creator_credit: Jeni Kendell, Craig Collie, Michael Daley, ABC-TV (Australia), CSIRO and Environmental Protection Authority, W A
results.brief_description: System 6 is the name given by the Environmental Protection Agency to the area around Perth. It includes the Darling Ranges and the Swan River System. The detrimental effect of the urban sprawl and industrialisation in the karri forests, on sand dunes, and under the sea, is examined. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jeni Kendell, Craig Collie, Michael Daley, ABC-TV (Australia), CSIRO and Environmental Protection Authority, W A

results.title: Symbolism in literature
results.creator_credit: Herman Epstein, Herb Schick, Noel Korn and Sigma Education Films
results.brief_description: The basic theories of symbolism are discussed as an introduction. Edgar Allen Poe’s chilling story, “The Tell Tale Heart”, helps us to uncover symbols and their meanings, enhancing our enjoyment and understanding of fiction. Also briefly discusses symbolism in Van Gogh’s work. Uses animation to accompany Poe’s story.

results.title: Sykes
results.brief_description: Sykes Williams is a blind, semi-retired musician, a great favourite in the small bar where he plays piano to supplement his social security benefits. He is seen on his daily excursions into his neighbourhood, and at the bar, as he eloquently expresses his opinions on a wide range of concerns. A portrait of an involved, vital human being as well as an exploration of the problems of the blind and ageing.

results.title: Sydney in sight
results.creator_credit: R.H. Materna and R H Materna Productions
results.brief_description: An impression of Sydney, against a background of light jazz and informal commentary. The Harbour, the city landmarks, the children, the relics of convict days; the rapid development of office blocks and hotels in the metropolis; sketches of Sydney’s people and their ways; Sydney telephones, Sydney traffic and the extreme quiet of a Sydney Sunday; weekend sports, the beaches and the night life of Kings Cross. Narrated by Michael Charlton. Music by Tony Hermann.

results.title: Sydney celebration: the opening ceremony 2000
results.brief_description: At sunset on Friday, September 15 2000, approximately 100,00 spectators (over 4 billion viewers worldwide) and over 12,000 performers celebrated the opening of the 27th Olympiad in Sydney, Australia. Ric Birch, Director of Ceremonies, and David Atkins, the artistic director, produced an epic pageant of Australian culture, from stockmen on horseback to an Aboriginal Corroboree and clan members representing the original Australians, an homage to our sea-loving nature to the modern dance numbers which represented current Australian lifestyles and attitudes. The ceremony concluded with the Olympic torch being borne around the Olympic stadium by a succession of female athletes, acknowledging 100 years of women’s participation in the Olympics, culminating with the Olympic flame being lit by Aboriginal track star Cathy Freeman.

results.title: Swiss Family Robinson
results.creator_credit: Ken Annakin, Peter Boita, Bill Anderson and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description:
One of Disney’s biggest and most fondly remembered films, chronicles the exploits of the Robinson family after they are shipwrecked on a deserted island. Using teamwork and ingenuity, they skillfully overcome the obstacles of nature but the ultimate challenge lies ahead when a band of pirates threatens their paradise. Stars John Mills, Dorothy McGuire, James MacArthur and Janet Munro.
From the novel “Swiss Family Robinson” by Johann Wyss

results.title: Swimmy
results.creator_credit: Giulio Gianini, Leo Lionni and Connecticut Films
results.brief_description: This prize-winning animated film is Leo Lionni’s own interpretation of his original fable about the small fish, Swimmy, which outwits the hungry tuna and leads the other fish in exploring the marvellous underwater world.

results.title: Swimming in the backyard
results.creator_credit: Polly Watkins, Beth Frey and Blackout Productions
results.brief_description: This short documentary was commissioned by SBS Independent as part of its ‘Australia by Numbers’ series about community life in various postcodes around Australia. This episode centres on the municipal pool in Prahran, an inner suburb of Melbourne. Every summer, since it was built in the 1960’s, the pool has been a magnet for a diverse range of locals who go there both to socialise and exercise. A constant over the years has been the pool’s two long serving managers, who know and are known by almost everyone.

results.title: Sweet smell of success [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alexander Mackendrick, James Hill and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This film noir has been well described as, ‘a rat trap of a film’, a compelling portrayal of corruption in which an unscrupulous small-time press agent, intent on clawing his way to the top, debases himself for the favours of a monster of a newspaper columnist. While it does not involve murder, the degree of manipulation and self deception is truly noir. Sidney Falco, the agent, is ultimately a more sympathetic figure because the cold bloodedness and self-righteous egomania of the columnist, J.J. Hunsecker, sets Falco’s faint glimmerings of self-disgust into relief. Susan Hunsecker, the object of her brother’s repressed incestuous desire, is the one figure who provides some moral bearings and delivers the retribution that J.J. fears. New York locations, aided by James Wong Howe’s night photography and Bernstein’s limpid jazz score, have never seemed bleaker. Featuring Burt Lancaster, Tony Curtis, Susan Harrison, Screenplay, Clifford Odets and Ernest Lehman from the novelette by Ernest Lehman.

results.title: Sweet love, bitter
results.creator_credit: Herbert Danska, Lewis Jacobs, Louis W Kellman and Film Three Productions
results.brief_description: Fictional chronicle depicting the last years of jazz musician’s Charlie ‘Bird’ Parker’s life. Capturing the trials and tribulations of a black musician in white America, this film takes an in-depth look at the multi-faceted world of the jazz life — music, drink, drugs, racism, women, and indifference. Features Dick Gregory in the key role as Richie ‘Eagle’ Stokes, with Don Murray playing a down-and-out professor. Adapted from the John A. Williams’ novel “Night song”.
